content.description:
A powerful compression line up the corner of the boulder. Sit start with your right hand in a thin seam and left hand on a sloping edge. Make a hard pull off the ground and slap left hand up to a decent slot. Find your feet and make one last desperate throw to a rad pinch. Continue to the top and finish with a less than straight forward topout. Great movement with really unique holds. 

  The first move might actually take away from the line and starting one move in felt around V5. 

  Worth trying if you're in the area.
content.protection: A pad or two to cover the rock behind you.
content.location: Just to the right of Stainless Steel. Climbs the corner of the boulder.

content.description: A solid, powerful problem with technical feet that would be classic if it didn't fly under the radar.  Sit start the left side of the slightly bulging face at a jug in the crack with your ass on the low boulder behind you.  Follow a seam to the right for a couple of moves, then using a right hand sidepull and a left hand crimp/sloper, dyno to a better hold up and right (crux).  Match the hold, then top out straight up.
content.location: This problem is on the Crack Boulder, visible from the trail, and around the corner to the left if you are looking at the Crack of Pain.

content.description:
I found this problem in the guidebook but the beta was fairly unclear.       I sit start left hip in. Left hand on a small sharp quartz crimp, right hand on the offset/sloper. Climb straight up and topout. 

  Its pretty straightforward after that, but so far, I havent made the first move.
content.location: On the center of the face as you walk up to the sorority boulder from the karma boulders.   Sit start and climb the offset seam/crack to the top.

content.description: Climb the mossy face directly up the middle of the slab on good edges and crimps.
content.location: Fairly obvious face climb to the right of Brett’s Arete.

content.description: Crimps, heelhooks, and a unique two-or-three finger pocket make this problem worth climbing once, but due to the awkwardness created by the boulder beneath the problem, once is probably enough.  Crouch start on the overhanging face with a slopey edge and pull up and right to a set of crimps.  The first move is probably the crux.  Get a heelhook, match the crimp, and move right again to another crimp before standing up into the pocket.  After some trickery the topout is simple.
content.protection: Pads & a spotter - falling may result in a backflop.
content.location: On the Karma boulder between the Crack Boulder and Pinnacle boulders, next to the Sorority boulder and visible from the trail.  Scramble down off the back.

content.description: Awesome overhanging arching arete climb.   Heel hook, slap and haul your butt up this classic line.    I wish this climb was 100 feet long...   Topout on huge jugs!
content.protection: Pad on the rock, maybe a spotter if you feel uneasy.
content.location: Left arete on the Soroity Boulder.

content.description:
You may have walked by this boulder many times and passed by this short arete with a fun albeit short route. 

  Sit start under the arete with a big foot and two very slopey holds, figure out the body position to make the slopers feel good. Pull up and hit a crimp out right then finish easily up the arete. Then weep because it is over far to soon...
content.location: This route is located on the small boulder ten feet away from the Crack Boulder. This short arete point towards "Brett's Arete"

content.description: Right arete climb on the Sorority Boulder.    Sit start on large hold, climb the arete using bad holds and body tension to easy topout on jugs.   Fun climb at the grade, for the area.
content.location: Rightmost problem on the Sorortiy Boulder.

content.description:
Stand start at the arete with a high left-hand crimp rail and a slopey friction dependent pinch on the arete. Find some feet and make a hard first move up to a positive hold in the horizontal crack system. Once here, match the crack and figure out a sequence to traverse the horizontal leftwards in order to gain the sharp, aesthetic, vertical crack. 

 Sharp locks and a scary landing means you better only get to the vertical section once from the start. Turn on that murder-face!
content.location: This problem shares the same start with "Brett's Arete" and traverse backwards through "Crackhead Left" and finishes on the incredible "Crack of Pain".

content.description: This fingery problem is one of the best moderates in the woods, but sadly it doesn't get much attention because nobody knows it's there.  It starts in a crack (same start as Crack of Pain), follows a thin seam out right to a juggy arete, and finishes up the arete with some fun moves.  Stand start with the vertical crack and some delicate feet.  Stay tight with bad feet and small pods in the seam and work right to gain a better slot and then a jug on the arete.  Work around the corner and straight up to the top.
content.location: On the Crack Boulder.  This problem is on the back (the side facing away from the trail).  Scramble off the boulder towards the trail.

content.description: This beautiful, vertical finger crack is usually avoided like the plague.  Nobody wants bloody fingers, do they?  Well, tape up, insert yourself into the fingerlocks, and climb straight up.
content.protection: Pads - there are a few small rocks at the base
content.location: On the Crack Boulder.  This crack splits the face on the back.  Scramble off the top towards the trail.

content.description:
Start on a good hand hold and OK feet. Move up the face using good holds. The start is the crux and once past it the climbing is progressively easier. The top out has really good holds made by a crack in the rock. 

  Walk off the back of the boulder.
content.protection: Pad and spotter because it is tall.
content.location: On the Crack Boulder this climbs the broken face to the right of the right arete of the Crack of Pain(V3) face. Its just left of the mossy face climb called Mamma Mia(V0).

content.description: Really more of a one-move wonder into easier V2 terrain, but it can be fun if your fingers are up for it.  Grab a left hand crimp on the otherwise blank face, pinch a sloper on the arete with your right hand, get a foot on, and pop to a jug on the arete.  Follow the arete straight up.
content.location: On the Crack Boulder, this problem climbs an arete on the side facing away from the trail.  Scramble down easy terrain towards the trail.

content.description:
Sit start with the right hand on the starting left hand crimp of "Bake Sale". Grab a sloper on the horizontal and choose a good foot. Cross right hand over to improving holds and figure out how to finish up the right leaning arete.  

  This problem is not listed in the guidebook. I'm fairly sure this problem has been done before. It contains fun, unique movement.

Hard for the grade!(for me)   Start on large rail (if you can hold on) in the middle of the face and try to move up to a cool pocket, change feet and climb up on flakes to topout that isn't bad. 

  This climb kills me...it looks so do-able but i just can't stick to the starting hold.
content.location: Central line on the Sorority Boulder.

content.description: These scattered boulders lie on either side of the trail between the junction and the Pinnacle Boulder.  The Crack Boulder, the first you'll encounter is home to the beautiful and aptly named Crack of Pain and the classic, powerful Stainless Steel.  The Karma Boulder is visible across a short marsh on the left side of the trail past the Crack Boulder and only has one established climb.  To the left of the Karma Boulder and at the end of the small marsh is the Sorority Boulder with a fine collection of problems.
